newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo naphtha prices dip, contango widens.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo naphtha prices dip, contango widens.

text.p: Tokyo naphtha prices fell in afternoon trade on Thursday with market sentiment dampened by arbitrage cargoes shipped to Asia from Europe, traders said.
"The market is oversupplied as many arbitrage cargoes remain unsold," one naphtha trader said.
Some traders estimated that about 700,000 to 800,000 tonnes of naphtha have been shipped to Asia since the arbitrage window from Europe opened in March.
Open-spec naphtha for second-half July was assessed at $203.50/204.50 per tonne, compared with late Wednesday levels of $204.00/206.00.
First-half July was quoted at $201.00/202.00. It was traded at $205.00 on Wednesday.
The contango in near-term spreads steepened amid weak sentiment for prompt cargoes, traders said.
Second-half June/second-half July was discussed at minus $6.00/minus $5.00 after it was traded at minus $4.00 and at minus $5.50 on Wednesday, traders said.

In low sulphur waxy residue (LSWR) trading, a Japanese refiner bought 200,000 barrels of straight-run LSWR from a Pertamina affiliate. The price for the cargo, to be lifted in the first half of May, was unavailable. --Tokyo Energy Desk
